column4: so edbian:  I should go to a usb live disk before I even think about fixing drivers
you can always use a sandybridge CPU with AES-NI
Oh, right, that's what matters.
yes
speedstep or amd cool'n'quiet. it's a good thing
but even when at 100% load, it's stuck there
this is also a desktop
ALL cpus for 5-10 years have powersaving built in
Yes, but they should turn off properly when i need more power
yes they do. run a program that uses the CPU and you will see
I'll try with phoronix.
what cpu is it?
and how did you check if it went up?
AMD Athlon 64 x2 5000+, hardinfo
use cat /proc/cpuinfo
it sounds like hardinfo is wrong
why would it be wrong.  It displayed the same thing
before stressing cpu, it was 1000 mhz, now it went up to 2600 mhz
cpuinfo is what the kernel sees. and on a linux system there is no higher authority thn the kernel. and the kernel says your CPU runs at 2600MHz
yes, and hardinfo says the same thing.  I don't understand why its wrong
that was before a stress test
switching between my IGP and discrete graphics needs the terminal. can't be done in X at all
